questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

 

This image shows the mid-clavicular line, xiphoid process, and costal margin.

 

The examiner marks a laterally convex line that runs from the third costal cartilage, which is located about three spaces below the second costal cartilage (as shown by the sternal angle), to the sixth costal cartilage. The distance between this line and the sternal margin is around 1.2 cm. This imply that the area designated matches the right atrium's surface marking.

 

An average adult's projected cardiac borders onto the front chest wall form a trapezium shape. The percussion approach can be used to map this out by checking for cardiac dullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct typically ascends in the posterior mediastinum and does not correspond to the surface marking in the image which is more anterior and lateral.

 

Option C. Inferomedial bronchopulmonary segments: These segments are located more inferiorly in the lung fields and do not correspond to the area marked which is on the chest wall at the level of the heart.

 

Option D. Hilum: The hilum of the lung, where structures enter and exit the lung, is located more laterally than the area marked. It does not align with the vertical placement of the right atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

 

  • ﻿﻿Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1-2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately
  • 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • ﻿﻿Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target cell: Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the postsplenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme..

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells: Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text:
The diagnosis for a 23-year-old patient presenting with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region of the head, and exhibiting histological findings of hair loss with haemorrhage into the follicular areas and mild perinuclear lymphocytic infiltrate, is what? 
(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichotillomania

 

From the given clinical features & histopathological features, diagnosis is Trichotillomania (TTM) / Trichotillosis / Hair pulling disorder.

 

Clinical features suggestive of Trichotillomania in the clinical vignette:

 

  • The clinical history revealing non scarring alopecia in the vertex region (Hair pulling and plucking is commonest from the scalp)
  • No signs of inflammation
  • Perifollicular hemorrhage

 

Diagnostic criteria for TTM include:

 

  • Recurrent pulling out of one’s own hair resulting in non-scarring hair loss.
  • An increasing sense of tension immediately before pulling out the hair or when attempting to resist the behaviour.
  • Pleasure, gratification, or relief when pulling out the hair.
  • The disturbance is not better accounted for by another mental disorder.
  • The disturbance provokes clinically marked distress and/or impairment in occupational, social, or other areas of functioning.
  • Histopathology: No / Minimal inflammation
  • Peribulbar hemorrhage - due to trauma from plucking of hair.
  • intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhage and intrafollicular pigment casts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia areata:

 

  • While it is characterized by non-scarring alopecia and can have lymphocytic infiltrate around the hair follicles, the hemorrhage is not a typical feature.
  • Generally presents as well-defined patches of hair loss.

 

Option B. Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It manifests as a diffuse or generalized hair shedding from the entire scalp rather than localized patches.
  • It's commonly due to stress, certain medications, or illnesses.
  • Histopathology would not typically show hemorrhage or the specific perinuclear infiltrate described.

 

Option C. Tinea infection:

 

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp.
  • It usually presents with scaling and possibly broken-off hairs.
  • Histological examination would show evidence of fungal elements (hyphae and spores) rather than hemorrhage or lymphocytic infiltrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histological findings of hair loss with follicular hemorrhage and mild lymphocytic infiltrate, the diagnosis is likely Trichotillomania.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 86 & 89, page nos 86.17 & 89.31

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no: 1695

choices.text: Strap his thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
Roll the patient and put on a hard board

questions.text: All of the following are done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately

 

This option is not a standard practice when transporting conscious polytrauma patients. Shifting a conscious patient to a lateral position and immediately moving them can risk further injury and discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strap his thorax, abdomen, and lower limbs on a stretcher: This is a common and necessary practice when transporting a conscious polytrauma patient. It helps secure the patient to the stretcher to prevent movement and further injury during transport.

 

Option B. Apply a cervical collar: This is done to immobilize the cervical spine, till a cervical injury is ruled out.

 

Option D. Roll the patient and put on a hardboard: Rolling a conscious polytrauma patient and placing them on a hardboard (spinal board) can be a part of the standard protocol for immobilizing the spine and minimizing movement during transport. This is done to prevent potential spinal cord injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with polytrauma are shifted in supine or prone position (not in lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface, in order to restrict the spinal movement.

 

As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients unless proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.

 

The patient is placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (Philadelphia collar) is applied.

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.text: Which of the following is true statement about Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most common cause is alcohol misuse, but other conditions that affect nutrition can also lead to Korsakoff syndrome. Its main feature is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory i.e., patients with Korsakoff syndrome can't acquire new information or recall recent events, but long-term memories from before the onset of the illness remain intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia: Refers to Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome and presents with a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. If left untreated, Wernicke's can progress to Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of long-term memory but intact personality: While long-term memories may be affected in Korsakoff syndrome, it is not a characteristic feature. Personality changes, apathy, and lack of insight can be seen.

 

Option D. Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall: Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects explicit memory (conscious recall of facts and events), not implicit memory (unconscious memory like skills).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is primarily associated with chronic alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) and often retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories). Confabulation is common, where patients fill memory gaps with fabricated information. Treatment involves thiamine replacement and abstaining from alcohol. It often follows or coexists with Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is an acute syndrome requiring immediate thiamine treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 38-40.

choices.text: Transfusion related circulatory overload

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals Were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110 min. What is the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transfusion related circulatory overload

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).

 

Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 h of a blood transfusion - acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, increased blood pressure (BP), acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.

 

TACO may occur due to rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products.

 

Prevented is by slow transfusion at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic: Allergic reactions to blood transfusions usually present with urticaria (hives), pruritus (itching), and sometimes anaphylaxis, but do not typically cause the significant hypertension and tachycardia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI is characterized by acute onset of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, leading to respiratory distress and hypoxemia during or within 6 hours of transfusion. However, TRALI typically presents with hypotension or normal blood pressure, not the significant hypertension seen here.

 

Option D. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: This reaction typically presents with fever, chills, and rigors, but does not cause the hemodynamic instability (hypertension and tachycardia) seen in TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) is a potential complication of blood transfusion, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions like CKD. It presents with respiratory distress, hypertension, and tachycardia and can be prevented by careful monitoring and slow transfusion.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fever and joint pain develops the following lesion on her nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig: Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Dengue:

 

  • While dengue fever is also a mosquito-borne viral infection leading to symptoms like fever, headache, and joint pains, it does not typically result in brownish pigmentation on the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mania

 

The patient's symptoms of overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination are indicative of a manic episode. Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypomania: Similar to mania but the symptoms are milder, last for at least 4 days, and don't significantly impair social or occupational functioning.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia: A mood disorder characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms that don't meet the full criteria for a manic or major depressive episode.

 

Option D. Schizomania: This term is not standard in psychiatric diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 365

questions.text: The persistence of ADHD in childhood increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence. ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, which can lead to difficulty in following rules, controlling behavior, and maintaining social norms. When these symptoms persist into adolescence, they can manifest as more serious behavioral problems, such as conduct disorder, characterized by aggressive, antisocial, or defiant behaviors.

 

Conduct disorder is a common progression from ADHD because the underlying impulsivity and lack of self-control associated with ADHD often worsen over time, particularly when untreated. This progression underscores the importance of early intervention in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Note - Children with ADHD are at risk of developing depression, antisocial personality disorder, substance use disorder, and conduct disorder as adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This disorder involves a consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations, and it is more associated with anxiety disorders rather than ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: This condition involves recurrent episodes of eating large quantities of food, often quickly and to the point of discomfort. It is associated more with emotional regulation issues rather than impulsivity or behavioral problems typical of ADHD.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: This disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures. It is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and does not have a direct link to ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The persistence of ADHD in childhood significantly increases the risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence, highlighting the need for early and effective management of ADHD symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was initially being treated with sertraline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and amitriptyline. Shortly after the change in medication, the patient developed agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

  

The patient’s symptoms of agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors are indicative of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs due to excessive serotonergic activity in the nervous system, usually as a result of combining medications that increase serotonin levels, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. In this case, the combination of sertraline (an SSRI), an MAO inhibitor, and amitriptyline (a TCA) significantly increases serotonin, leading to the development of serotonin syndrome.

 

Symptoms of Serotonin Syndrome: (Mnemonic – RASH D)

 

  • Restlessness
  • Agitation
  • Seizures
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Diarrhea

 

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with serotonin receptor antagonist properties, making it the drug of choice for treating serotonin syndrome. It works by blocking serotonin receptors, thereby reducing the excessive serotonergic activity causing the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used to manage agitation and seizures but does not directly treat the underlying cause of serotonin syndrome. It is used as supportive therapy but is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is a supplement often used in metabolic conditions and does not play a role in treating serotonin syndrome. It has no effect on serotonin levels or receptor activity.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used as a rescue agent in methotrexate toxicity and other specific conditions. It has no role in the management of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin syndrome can occur when serotonergic drugs are combined, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. The treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome is Cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?(INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  1, 2

 

The Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles are components of the pelvic diaphragm, commonly referred to as the levator ani.

 

The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition between the true pelvis and the perineum. It is formed by the large levator ani and small coccygeus muscles of two sides and their covering fasciae.

 

 

1. Iliococcygeus: The iliococcygeus is one of the muscles that form the pelvic diaphragm. It is part of the levator ani muscle group. The levator ani consists of the iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. The iliococcygeus muscle extends from the ischial spine (a bony projection in the pelvis) to the coccyx (the tailbone) and contributes to the support of the pelvic floor.
 

2. Pubococcygeus: The pubococcygeus muscle is another component of the levator ani muscle group and is a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It extends from the pubic bone to the coccyx and helps maintain pelvic organ support and control.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Obturator Internus: The obturator internus is not considered a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It is a separate muscle located in the pelvic region, and its primary function is to laterally rotate the thigh. While it is near the pelvic diaphragm, it does not contribute to its formation.
 

4. Deep Transverse Perinei: The deep transverse perineal muscles are not typically considered part of the pelvic diaphragm. These muscles are located in the perineum (the area between the anus and the genitalia) and play a role in stabilizing the perineal body and supporting the pelvic organs. They are important for urinary and fecal continence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles (part of the levator ani muscle group). The obturator internus and deep transverse perineal muscles are nearby but are not considered part of the pelvic diaphragm itself.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency and is found to have raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis. The mother reports that she saw her consuming a substance in an unknown dose. What is the likely substance? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

  

The patient presents with symptoms of sympathetic overactivity, including raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis (excessive sweating), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These symptoms are characteristic of stimulant intoxication, particularly with substances that increase the release of catecholamines, such as cocaine. Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system stimulant that induces a surge of dopamine, leading to intense sympathetic activation, which matches the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that causes respiratory and cardiovascular depression, pinpoint pupils (miosis), and reduced sympathetic activity, which is the opposite of what is observed in this case.

 

Option C. Heroin: Like morphine, heroin is an opioid that results in symptoms of sedation, respiratory depression, and miosis, rather than the sympathetic overdrive seen here.

 

Option D. Chlordiazepoxide: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that acts as a sedative and anxiolytic. It would typically cause sedation, hypotension, and muscle relaxation, not the heightened sympathetic response observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine intoxication is associated with signs of sympathetic overactivity, including elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

Given scenario of an elderly male with obstructive jaundice and distended gall bladder, is suggestive of periampullary tumour. The best investigation would be a CECT abdomen (not provided in the option) or MRCP.

 

Correct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that visualizes the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It provides detailed images without the need for ionizing radiation or invasive procedures. Given the patient's age and presentation, MRCP is an ideal choice to visualize obstructions or abnormalities in the bile duct system without posing additional risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This is a useful modality for visualizing the biliary tree, pancreas, and surrounding structures. It can be particularly helpful in assessing small lesions or stones that might be missed by other imaging modalities. It would be utilised if MRCP/CECT did not yield adequate diagnosis, or for staging of periampullary tumors.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography: This is an invasive procedure where contrast is injected directly into the biliary system through the liver, and then X-rays are taken. It can be diagnostic as well as therapeutic (e.g., for bile duct drainage). However, it's more invasive than MRCP and might not be the first choice for solely diagnostic purposes in a 72-year-old patient.

 

Option D. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It involves inserting an endoscope through the mouth to the duodenum and injecting contrast into the bile and pancreatic ducts. While ERCP can visualize and treat obstructions, it's invasive and carries risks like pancreatitis, especially if used primarily for diagnostic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete

 

Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.

 

The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Mitochondrial inheritance (A) is associated with Leber's disease (3). Mitochondrial inheritance, also called maternal inheritance, occurs when DNA in the mitochondria is passed from mother to offspring. Leber's optic neuropathy is a classic example of a mitochondrial disease transmitted through maternal inheritance. This is because mitochondrial DNA is present in the ovum but not in sperm.

 

 

X-linked recessive inheritance (B) is linked to Duchene's muscular dystrophy (4). In XLR inheritance, the disease is more common in males since they only have one X chromosome. Duchene's muscular dystrophy is specifically listed as an example of X-linked recessive disorders.

 

Autosomal recessive inheritance (C) corresponds to cystic fibrosis (2). AR disorders require two copies of the mutated gene to manifest the disease and are common in consanguineous marriages. Cystic fibrosis is a classic example of an autosomal recessive disorder affecting enzymatic proteins.

 

Trinucleotide repeat disorders (D) include spinobulbar dystrophy (1). These disorders are characterized by expansion of nucleotide repeats during gametogenesis, leading to neurological diseases. The unstable expansion of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) causes spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Genetic Disorders and Their Inheritance Patterns

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed a normal uterus, but gonads weren't detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Swyer's syndrome

 

The clinical scenario described is indicative of Swyer syndrome, which is characterized by a 46XY karyotype and gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Key points about Swyer syndrome:

 

  • Swyer syndrome, also known as 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, is a condition where individuals with an XY karyotype present phenotypically as females.
  • These patients have a normal uterus and vagina but lack functioning gonads, which are often termed "streak gonads."
  • Because of gonadal dysgenesis, these individuals do not secrete testosterone or Antimullerian Hormone (AMH), leading to the development of female genital organs and phenotype.
  • Clinical presentation includes primary amenorrhea, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, and female external genitalia despite a 46XY karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Also known as testicular feminization syndrome, individuals have a 46XY karyotype but are phenotypically female with well-developed breasts and absent axillary and pubic hair. The gonads are testes, and there is no uterus.

 

Option B. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45XO karyotype. Patients typically present with short stature, shield chest, cubitus valgus, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and streak ovaries.

 

Option C. True hermaphrodite: True hermaphrodites have both ovarian and testicular tissue present, which is not consistent with the clinical scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Swyer syndrome (46XY gonadal dysgenesis) is a condition where individuals with a 46XY karyotype present phenotypically as females with primary amenorrhea, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and a normal uterus but lack functioning gonads.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 33446, Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg373

choices.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

 

The different levels of triage in emergency care are immediate, delayed, and minimal triage.

 

Immediate triage (red tag) is the highest priority and is given to patients who have life-threatening injuries or illnesses that require prompt medical attention. Examples of immediate triage include patients with severe bleeding or difficulty breathing.

 

Delayed triage (yellow tag) is given to patients who have injuries or illnesses that are not immediately life-threatening but require medical attention. Examples of delayed triage include patients with open fractures or moderate burns.

 

Minimal triage (green tag) is given to patients who have minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention. Examples of minimal triage include patients with minor cuts or bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.”

 

  • It first affects the involuntary muscles first starting with the myocardium
  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis in voluntary muscles
  • Order of appearance of Rigor mortis in different organs:

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST

 

The clinical presentation and the biopsy results suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, and it typically arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria. GISTs are often associated with symptoms of mass effect, such as abdominal pain and discomfort, and can lead to weight loss and loss of appetite. The diagnosis of GIST is confirmed by immunohistochemistry, which typically shows positivity for KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells. Other immunohistochemical markers such as LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are negative. Treatment options for GIST may include surgery, radiation therapy, or targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a common type of cancer that can occur in various organs, including the stomach. However, the immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100) are not characteristic of adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that typically presents with enlarged lymph nodes and is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question are not consistent with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is commonly associated with the epithelial lining of organs, and its diagnosis would typically involve positive staining for cytokeratin. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (negative for cytokeratin) do not support the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: A patient, who consumed a large number of TCA pills during a depressive episode, presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. What is the next best step in treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NAHCO3

 

A patient presenting with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG following an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) requires immediate treatment to address the cardiotoxic effects of the overdose. The best next step in this scenario is the administration of intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate (NAHCO3). Sodium Bicarbonate is used to treat the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs, which is responsible for the wide QRS complexes. It works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DC Cardioversion: This is generally used for unstable patients with life-threatening arrhythmias. In the case of TCA overdose, the priority is to treat the underlying cause of the arrhythmia (the sodium channel blockade), which is more effectively addressed with sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option B. Start antiarrhythmic drug: The use of antiarrhythmic drugs may be risky in the setting of TCA overdose, as these medications can exacerbate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because there is a clear and specific treatment indicated for this scenario, which is the administration of Sodium Bicarbonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

The presentation of a 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use, who is experiencing confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, and sixth nerve palsy, is highly suggestive of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. This is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (such as nystagmus and cranial nerve palsies), and ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome that often follows Wernicke's Encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and behavioral changes but lacks the acute neurological symptoms such as nystagmus and ataxia seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. While confusion is common, the specific neurological findings of nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy are more indicative of Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: Also known as erotomania, this is a delusional disorder characterized by the belief that another person is in love with the individual. It is unrelated to the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text:
What is/are correct statement(s) regarding skeletal muscle? (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Extracellular calcium entry is important in the skeletal muscle contraction.
  2. Calcium is mainly released from mitochondria.
  3. Calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  4. Voltage-gated calcium channel on sarcolemma has no role in excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Only 3

 

The accurate fact concerning skeletal muscle is that the release of calcium occurs from the sarcoplasmic reticulum only.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Extracellular calcium plays a significant role in sustaining cardiac muscle contraction , not in skeletal muscle.

 

2. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is filled with high concentrations of calcium ions stored in its vesicular tubules. Upon the occurrence of an action potential in the neighboring T tubule, these calcium ions are discharged from each vesicle.

 

4. Activation of  voltage-gated calcium channel is essential in excitation-contraction coupling, i.e. it a has important role. Activation of receptor results in the initiation of calcium release from RyR channels, leading to the liberation of calcium ions from the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils, consequently triggering muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is essential for skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following differentials should not be considered for the lesion seen in the image developed in a forest officer?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

 

Eschar can be noted in the given image, and Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is not a possible differential diagnosis for eschar.

  • KFD is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic in South India.
  • The primary clinical manifestations of KFD are fever, headache, severe muscle pain, followed by haemorrhagic symptoms like haemorrhages in the skin, mucosa & viscera, petechial lesions are characteristic skin lesions observed.
  • It is more known for its neurological and hemorrhagic manifestations but NOT Eschar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Scrub typhus (chigger-borne typhus)

 

  • The infective agent of scrub typhus, Orientia tsutsugamushi (Previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi), is conveyed to humans from its natural rodent reservoir by the bites of the Trombiculid mite.

 

 

  • Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers.
  • The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The primary lesion, or eschar, is a firm papule up to 1 mm in diameter surmounted by a vesicle, which dries to form a black crust.

 

Option C: Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porters’ disease)

 

  • Anthrax is a zoonotic infection with Bacillus anthracis.
  • Between 1 and 5 days after infection, an irritable papule develops at the site of inoculation. A bulla on a red oedematous base soon follows.
  • The bulla ruptures and forms a haemorrhagic crust which will undergo necrosis. Surrounding this several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.
  • This is called as Malignant pustule as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D: Healing brown recluse spider bite.

 

Bite of Loxosceles reclusa (Loxoscelism) → Target lesion develops → Development of eschar → Heals with Ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kyasanur Forest Disease tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever, primarily presenting with haemorrhagic and neurological symptoms, should not be considered for skin lesion, Eschar, unlike the other mentioned differentials.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.33

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 249, 250, 415, 530

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orgasm

 

This phase involves the release of sexual tension. Premature ejaculation and anorgasmia are disorders of this phase.

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It involves ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired, often with minimal sexual stimulation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Desire: This phase refers to the interest in engaging in sexual activity. Disorders of this phase might manifest as hypoactive sexual desire disorder or sexual aversion disorder.

 

Option B. Arousal: This phase is characterized by physiological changes such as erection in men and vaginal lubrication in women. Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of this phase in men.

 

Option D. Pain: This isn't a phase of the sexual response cycle. However, dyspareunia refers to pain during intercourse and can be a clinical condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It is characterized by a pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after the vaginal penetration.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 579.

choices.text: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid

questions.text: Which of the following is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid


Fibrinolytic therapy involves the use of drugs (like alteplase, streptokinase, etc.) to break down blood clots. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) and tranexamic acid are antifibrinolytic agents that can be used to counteract bleeding due to excessive fibrinolysis, which can occur during or after fibrinolytic therapy. These work by inhibiting plasminogen activators and, to a lesser degree, plasmin activity, thereby reducing the breakdown of fibrin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine Sulphate: This is used as an antidote for heparin overdose, not for fibrinolytic therapy. Protamine sulphate binds to and inactivates heparin.

 

Option B. Dalteparin: Dalteparin is a low molecular weight heparin and is an anticoagulant itself. It is not used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Option D. Alteplase: Alteplase is a fibrinolytic agent, not an antidote. It is used to dissolve blood clots in conditions like acute ischemic stroke, pulmonary embolism, and myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy, used to counteract excessive bleeding due to fibrinolysis. It works by inhibiting plasminogen activators and stabilizing clots.

questions.text: All of the following methods of cold sterilization except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autoclave

 

Cold sterilization refers to sterilization methods that do not involve heat application. Autoclave operates at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, making it a hot sterilization method rather than a cold sterilization technique.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Plasma sterilization: 

 

  • This is a valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses gases in plasma state without temperature increase
  • Effective for heat-sensitive materials

 

Option B. Gamma rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses ionizing radiation
  • Does not increase temperature
  • Commonly used for medical devices and supplies

 

Option C. UV rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses non-ionizing radiation
  • Does not generate heat
  • Effective for surface sterilization

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autoclave is a hot sterilization method operating at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, while plasma sterilization, gamma rays, and UV rays are cold sterilization methods that do not involve heat application.

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?(NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acrophobia

 

This is the fear of heights.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarophobia: This is the fear of itching or of the insects that cause itching.

 

Option B. Algophobia: This is the fear of pain.

 

Option C. Agoraphobia: This is the fear of open spaces or of being in crowded, public places like markets, or the fear of leaving a safe place, often associated with panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acrophobia refers to the fear of heights.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Among the OCD subtypes, hoarding has shown to be more resistant to treatment with ERP. This might be because individuals with hoarding disorder often do not recognize their behavior as problematic and may lack insight into the disorder.

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy that is effective for many individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, certain subtypes or themes of OCD might respond less effectively to ERP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: While challenging, ERP can be tailored to address pathological doubt by creating exposures that trigger doubt without seeking reassurance.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: ERP can also be adapted for magical thinking by exposing the individual to the feared situation or thought without engaging in the ritualistic behavior.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: Contamination fears are typically one of the subtypes that respond quite well to ERP, as the therapist can create direct exposures involving the feared contaminant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hoarding disorder is characterised by acquiring and not being able to discard things that are considered to have little or no use. This will lead to cluttering of house, to an extent that it becomes unsafe to live. This disorder is driven by fear of losing something important. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.  Hoarding disorder tends to have a poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.

 

 

 

Y- chromosome 

 

The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.

 

Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

 

The symptoms described are indicative of panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort that may include palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, and feelings of impending doom. These attacks can occur unexpectedly or in anticipation of a specific trigger, such as before an exam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms not explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition.

 

Option C. Social anxiety disorder is characterized by an intense fear of social situations.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities most days for at least 6 months, not limited to performance situations like exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom. The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text:
BRCA 1 gene is associated with______:

 

  1. Repair of ds DNA break
  2. Risk of development of ovarian cancer
  3. Tumor suppressor gene
  4. Mutation is seen in the subset of Fanconi anemia
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

The statements associated with the BRCA1 gene are:

 

  • Repair of double-stranded (ds) DNA breaks: BRCA1 plays a critical role in the repair process of ds DNA breaks through homologous recombination.
  • Risk of development of ovarian cancer: Women with mutations in the BRCA1 gene have a higher risk of developing ovarian cancer, in addition to breast cancer.
  • Tumor suppressor gene: BRCA1 is classified as a tumor suppressor gene, meaning it helps to prevent uncontrolled cell division and tumor growth by repairing DNA damage.

 

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes that protect against certain cancers. Mutations in these genes increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancers, especially in women. They also play an essential role in the repair of DNA damage through homologous recombination, which fixes double-strand DNA breaks.

 

Mutations in BRCA1 do not commonly cause Fanconi anemia, although mutations in BRCA2 are more commonly linked to a subset of Fanconi anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1,3,4: While BRCA1 is associated with DNA repair and is a tumor suppressor gene, it is not commonly linked to Fanconi anemia, which is more associated with BRCA2 mutations.

 

Option C. 2,3,4: Although the BRCA1 mutation increases the risk of ovarian cancer and functions as a tumor suppressor, its connection to Fanconi anemia is more relevant to BRCA2 mutations, not BRCA1.

 

Option D. 1,2,4: While BRCA1 plays a role in DNA repair and is linked to ovarian cancer risk, it is not associated with Fanconi anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene primarily associated with the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks, the development of breast and ovarian cancer, and it functions to suppress tumor formation. BRCA2 mutations are more commonly linked to Fanconi anemia.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction limitation

 

This is not a feature of third nerve palsy. Abduction of the eye is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve. Limitation in abduction is indicative of sixth nerve palsy, not third nerve palsy. In third nerve palsy, there would be a limitation of adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose) instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) presents with several characteristic features due to the loss of function of the muscles it innervates:

 

Option A. Pupil dilatation: The third cranial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction. Damage to this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic stimulation, leading to pupil dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option B. Ptosis: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, responsible for elevating the eyelid, is innervated by the third cranial nerve. Damage to this nerve causes ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option C. Down and out eye: The unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the sixth cranial nerve) and the superior oblique (innervated by the fourth cranial nerve) results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the affected eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third nerve palsy presents with pupil dilatation, ptosis, and a down and out eye. Abduction limitation is not a feature of third nerve palsy; it is seen in sixth nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. This approach allows for the direct sampling of the lesion to assess for malignancy or other pathological changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conisation: Conisation is an excisional procedure that is typically performed once biopsy-proven cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step for a visible mass with postcoital bleeding.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure used for treating CIN1 or 2. It is not suitable for initial diagnosis or for lesions suspected of being malignant.

 

Option D. Pap smear: A Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. It is a screening tool and not diagnostic for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a symptomatic patient with a visible cervical lesion and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is the appropriate next step to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: Page 327, DC Dutta’a Textbook of gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gunshot wound

 

The given image is of a gunshot wound.

 

Features of gunshot wound:

 

  • Central round hole with surrounding soot soiling.

  • Burnt hairs (singeing).

  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles (tattooing).

  • Bevelling of edges (Exit Wounds)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tattooing: While tattooing refers to punctate skin lesions caused by powder particles in gunshot wounds, it alone does not describe the entirety of the image shown.

 

Option C. Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning typically causes symptoms like skin changes, but not the characteristic central hole and surrounding soot seen in gunshot wounds.

 

Option D. Graze wound: A graze wound is typically a superficial wound caused by the bullet skimming the surface of the skin, which looks different from the wound shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gunshot wound can be identified by its central round hole, surrounding soot, singeing of hairs, tattooing from powder particles, and bevelling of the wound edges.

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a toxin of abuse potential? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erythroxylum coca

 

The plant in the picture is Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by red berries.

 

Cocaine, a substance with significant abuse potential, is derived from this plant.

 

Other Options

 

Option B Datura: It can be identified by:

 

  • Green color fruit with sharp spines
  • Large trumpet shaped flowers

 

Datura flower and fruit images shown below:

 

 

Option C Digitalis Purpura: It can be identified by: 

 

  • Leaves are spirally arranged and covered with gray-white hairs, imparting a woolly texture.
  • Flowers are arranged in an elongated cluster, and each flower is tubular and pendent.

 

Digitalis purpura Flower and Plant images shown below:

 

 

Option D Cannabis: It can be identified by: 

 

  • Leaves have a digitate shape, with serrated edges. Leaflets are arranged opposite each other along the stem and are usually symmetrically aligned.

 

Cannabis leaves images shown below:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine is obtained from Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by following features:

 

  • Leaves: Characteristic of the leaf is an areolated portion bounded by two longitudinal curved lines, one line on each side of the midrib.
  • Flowers are small, and disposed in little clusters on short stalks.
  • Red Berries: The flowers mature into red berries.

questions.text:
Consider the causes of alopecia. Which among the following cause(s) non-scarring alopecia? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Non-scarring alopecia is caused by androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium (1, 2, and 3). Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease associated with several autoimmune conditions, including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. It mainly affects the scalp, but may also involve the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, it can lead to total hair loss on the scalp (alopecia totalis) or the entire body (alopecia universalis).
  • Telogen effluvium is a type of non-scarring alopecia marked by diffuse shedding of normal hair due to the premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle. It can be either acute or chronic:
    • Acute telogen effluvium typically occurs 2–3 months after stressful events such as high fever, surgery, or postpartum hormonal changes (telogen gravidarum). This condition often resolves spontaneously.
    • Chronic telogen effluvium persists for more than six months and is often associated with thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, or malnutrition.
  • Androgenetic alopecia is a non-scarring alopecia characterized by a reduction in hair fiber production and follicle miniaturization. It is related to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), an androgenic metabolite, and has two forms:
    • Male-pattern hair loss typically causes frontal hairline recession and vertex thinning.
    • Female-pattern hair loss results in mid-frontal scalp thinning with minimal involvement of the temporal region.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia, on the other hand, is a type of scarring (cicatricial) alopecia, leading to permanent hair loss due to follicular destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3 and 4: While androgenic alopecia (option 3) causes non-scarring alopecia, frontal fibrosing alopecia (option 4) is a scarring form of alopecia, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. 2, 3, and 4: Although telogen effluvium (option 2) and androgenic alopecia (option 3) are types of non-scarring alopecia, frontal fibrosing alopecia (option 4) is scarring, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Only 4: Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scarring type of alopecia, so it cannot be classified as non-scarring, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-scarring alopecia includes androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium. These conditions result in hair loss that does not involve permanent destruction of the hair follicles, distinguishing them from scarring types of alopecia like frontal fibrosing alopecia.

questions.text: Which of the following actions leads to an increase in acetylcholine (ACh) release from the presynaptic neuron?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium channel blocker

 

Potassium channel blockers increase acetylcholine (ACh) release from the presynaptic neuron. Blocking potassium channels prolongs depolarization of the neuron, which enhances the influx of calcium through voltage-gated calcium channels. This increased calcium entry then promotes greater ACh release at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Aminopyridines, which are potassium channel blockers, are used in the treatment of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome to improve muscle strength by increasing ACh release.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium channel blocker: Blocking sodium channels would reduce neuronal depolarization, thus decreasing calcium entry and subsequently reducing ACh release.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blocker: Blocking calcium channels would directly prevent calcium influx, leading to a decrease in ACh release from the presynaptic neuron.

 

Option D. Chlorine channel blocker: Chlorine (chloride) channels do not directly affect ACh release. Chloride ions typically stabilize the membrane potential, so blocking them would not specifically increase ACh release.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Potassium channel blockers enhance acetylcholine release by prolonging neuronal depolarization and increasing calcium influx at the presynaptic terminal.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Derailment

 

Formal thought disorders refer to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought, rather than the content of thought.

 

Here, the association between two successive thoughts is disturbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obsession: It refers to recurrent, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts. It's more related to possession than the form of thought.

 

Option C. Delusion: It is a false belief that is unshakeable and cannot be explained on the basis of a person's social and cultural background.It is a disorder of thought content.

 

Option D. Thought insertion: It is the belief that certain of one's thoughts are not one's own, but rather are inserted into one's mind. This is also a possession of thought, not its form.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Formal thought disorders pertain to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought. Derailment, loose associations, neologisms are examples of a formal thought disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 10

questions.text: In case of a chemical injury to the eye, what is the immediate first step in the management? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Copious irrigation with saline

 

Explanation: 


In chemical injury to the eye, copious irrigation with saline is the immediate first step in management. The primary goal is to remove the offending agent as quickly as possible to minimize tissue damage. Irrigation should be started immediately using whatever solution is available (saline, Ringer's lactate, balanced salt solution, or even plain water). It's crucial not to use neutralizing solutions (like acid for alkali or vice versa) as this can generate heat and cause additional damage.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Check visual acuity: This is incorrect as checking visual acuity would delay the urgent need to remove the causative chemical agent. Visual acuity can be checked after initial irrigation.

 

Option B. Take history: This is incorrect. While history is important, it should not delay immediate irrigation. Basic history (type of chemical) can be taken while performing irrigation.

 

Option C. Intraocular pressure measurement: This is incorrect. IOP measurement has no role in immediate management of chemical injury and could potentially cause more harm if done before thorough irrigation.

 

Educational Objective: 


Immediate copious irrigation with saline or any available appropriate solution is the first step in managing chemical injury to the eye, taking precedence over all other examinations or investigations.

questions.text: Which drug would be most effective in preventing withdrawal symptoms in a patient with a history of alcohol consumption who was admitted to the hospital after a road traffic accident? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like anxiety, tremors, seizures, and delirium tremens, which can be life-threatening. Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, work by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the nervous system, thereby reducing the risk of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This drug is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, not for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reduce cravings and prevent relapse in patients recovering from alcohol or opioid dependence. It is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used for the management of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It is not effective for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the drugs of choice to prevent and manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female with diabetes mellitus has experienced a decrease in her HbA1c levels from 7.6 to 6.7 after starting a new oral medication. Laboratory tests show that she has high levels of GIP and GLP-1 and low levels of glucagon. Which of the following oral drugs was most likely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alogliptin.

 

Alogliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, an oral class of drugs used in the treatment of diabetes. DPP-4 inhibitors work by preventing the breakdown of GLP-1, thereby increasing the levels of GLP-1 in the body, which in turn enhances insulin secretion, reduces glucagon secretion, and slows gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voglibose: Voglibose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays the absorption of carbohydrates in the intestines. It does not directly affect the levels of incretin hormones like GLP-1 and GIP, nor does it significantly influence glucagon levels.

 

Option C. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analogue that is used to help control blood sugar levels. It is typically administered by injection and does not significantly increase GLP-1 or GIP levels. It works by slowing gastric emptying and suppressing glucagon secretion, but it does not match the profile described in the question as closely as alogliptin.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist, which would indeed lead to increased GLP-1 levels and decreased glucagon levels. However, liraglutide is administered by injection and not orally. This makes it less likely to be the medication described in the scenario, which specifies an oral drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alogliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, is the most likely drug responsible for the increase in GLP-1 and GIP levels and the decrease in glucagon levels in this patient. It effectively lowers HbA1c levels and is administered orally, fitting the description provided.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Only aspirin is given
  2. Warfarin is given
  3. Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
  4. Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

For a patient with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, particularly one with a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA), anticoagulation therapy is essential.

 

2. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant in cases of severe mitral stenosis due to its proven effectiveness in preventing thromboembolic events.

 

3. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in this scenario as they are not indicated for patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Aspirin alone is insufficient to prevent stroke in this context.

 

4. Mitral valvotomy is not recommended at this point because performing the procedure could dislodge existing clots, leading to embolic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, especially those with a history of TIA, Warfarin should be given for stroke prevention, and direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated.

choices.text: Androgen insensitivity Syndrome

questions.text: 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination she has well developed secondary sexual characters and labs revealed a normal LH and FSH. Her karyotype is 46XX. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian Agenesis

 

Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. The key features supporting this diagnosis are:

 

  1. Primary amenorrhea in a 16-year-old girl
  2. Well-developed secondary sexual characters
  3. Normal LH and FSH levels
  4. 46,XX karyotype

 

In Mullerian agenesis, the uterus and upper vagina fail to develop properly, but the ovaries function normally. This explains the presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal hormone levels, despite the absence of menstruation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Gonadal Dyagenesis: Incorrect because patients with gonadal dysgenesis typically have high FSH and LH levels due to lack of negative feedback from functioning gonads. They also often lack secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome: Incorrect, isolated GnRH deficiency which is characterized by low LH and FSH levels, absent secondary sexual characteristics, and often associated with anosmia (loss of smell). The patient in this case has normal hormone levels and well-developed secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: Incorrect because this condition has a 46,XY karyotype, not 46,XX as in this case. Additionally, individuals with complete AIS would present with female external genitalia but lack a uterus and ovaries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome) presents with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, normal hormone levels (LH and FSH), and a 46,XX karyotype.

choices.text: Closure of tricuspid valve
Onset of ventricular systole
Maximal atrial filling

questions.text: 'a' wave in JVP corresponds to? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrial contraction

 

The 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) represents right atrial contraction. This occurs towards the end of ventricular diastole and reflects the pressure increase within the right atrium as it contracts to push blood into the right ventricle just before the tricuspid valve closes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Closure of tricuspid valve: Incorrect, this would not be specifically represented by an 'a' wave; instead, it typically follows the 'a' wave and leads into the 'c' wave associated with right ventricular contraction.

 

Option C. Onset of ventricular systole: Incorrect, ventricular systole corresponds to the 'c' wave and the 'x' descent on JVP.

 

Option D. Maximal atrial filling: Incorrect, maximal atrial filling occurs towards the end of the 'v' wave and into the 'y' descent, which corresponds to passive ventricular filling when the tricuspid valve is open.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Harrison/Cardiology/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

choices.text: Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius

questions.text: All the following are criteria for SIRS, except ______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic BP <90 mmHg

 

Systolic BP <90 mmHg is not a criterion for SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome).

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following criteria are present:

 

  1. Hyperthermia (>38°C) or hypothermia (<36°C)
  2. Tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO₂) <32 mmHg
  3. Tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute)
  4. White blood cell count >12 × 10⁹/L or <4 × 10⁹/L, or >10% band forms (immature neutrophils)

 

Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38°C or <36°C: Is a part of the SIRS criteria.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 breaths/min: Is a criterion for SIRS (tachypnea).

 

Option D. Heart rate >90/min: (tachycardia) is also one of the criteria for SIRS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SIRS criteria include hyperthermia/hypothermia, tachycardia, tachypnea, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic BP is not included as a direct diagnostic criterion for SIRS.

choices.text: Analysis, Blinding, Inclusion and Exclusion, Randomization
Blinding, Inclusion and Exclusion, Randomization, Analysis,
Inclusion and Exclusion, Randomization, Blinding, Analysis
Inclusion and Exclusion, Blinding, Randomization, Analysis

questions.text: Among the following, mark the correct sequence of steps for a Randomized controlled trial (RCT)? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Inclusion and Exclusion, Randomization, Blinding, Analysis

 

  • The correct sequence for the steps of a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) is first defining the inclusion and exclusion criteria, then randomization, followed by blinding, and finally analysis of results. 
  • This sequence follows the logical flow of conducting an RCT.
  • RCT protocol includes first making a protocol that defines aims, objectives, and hypothesis. 
  • Then the steps proceed as: 
    1. Defining the target population
    2. Making inclusion and exclusion criteria
    3. Randomization
    4. Blinding of intervention 
    5. Analysis of results

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of steps in conducting a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): defining inclusion and exclusion criteria, randomization, blinding, and finally analysis.
