questions.text: What does this Cardio-Tocography show?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deceleration

 

Explanation:

 

The Cardio-Tocography (CTG) in question shows decelerations, which are characterized by a drop in the fetal heart rate (FHR) by at least 15 beats per minute (bpm) lasting for at least 15 seconds.

 

Types of Decelerations on CTG:

 

  1. Early Deceleration:
    • The nadir (lowest point) of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the uterine contraction.
    • Caused by head compression during contractions.
    • Commonly observed in the second stage of labor.
  2. Late Deceleration:
    • The nadir of the deceleration occurs after the peak of the contraction.
    • Indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency, which can lead to fetal distress or hypoxia.
    • Considered an ominous sign and requires prompt evaluation and intervention.
  3. Variable Deceleration:
    • There is no fixed relationship between the deceleration and uterine contractions.
    • Caused by umbilical cord compression, often seen with oligohydramnios.
    • Significant if persistent, with FHR <70 bpm for more than 60 seconds.
  4. Prolonged Deceleration:
    • Occurs when the deceleration lasts beyond 2 minutes but less than 10 minutes.
    • May indicate acute fetal hypoxia, such as with cord prolapse or intrapartum abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acceleration: This would show an increase in the fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Normal: A normal CTG would not show any decelerations or would show a typical pattern of fetal heart rate variability and accelerations.

 

Option D. Deceleration followed by acceleration: This pattern would indicate a combination of deceleration and acceleration, which is not specified here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decelerations on a Cardio-Tocography indicate a decrease in fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, with different types signifying various conditions and levels of concern.

 

Ref: Page no 994, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

 

The Anti-D vaccine (anti-D immunoglobulin) is typically administered to prevent Rh sensitization in Rh-negative women who might be exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood. It is given to protect against the formation of anti-Rh antibodies that could affect future pregnancies. The vaccine is not given after an intrauterine transfusion because this procedure is performed to treat severe fetal anemia in cases where the mother is Rh-positive or the indirect Coombs test (ICT) is positive, indicating that the mother has already been sensitized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis at 16 weeks: Anti-D vaccine is given after amniocentesis to prevent Rh sensitization, as the procedure can cause fetal blood to mix with maternal blood.

 

Option B. Manual removal of placenta: Anti-D vaccine is administered after manual removal of the placenta to prevent sensitization, as this procedure can result in significant feto-maternal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. MTP at 63 days: Anti-D vaccine is given after medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) to prevent Rh sensitization if the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-D vaccine is not given after intrauterine transfusion, as this procedure is used to treat severe fetal anemia and does not require further prophylaxis against Rh sensitization.

 

Ref: Page no 919, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Dr. Rajan is a consultant at a primary health center, frequently encountering cases of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs). He usually prefers syndromic approach for managing these conditions due to limited diagnostic facilities. A 28-year-old male patient walks in, presenting with discharge from his urethra, indicating a possible urethritis. The patient is unaware of the specific causative organism. Given the syndromic management approach, which combination of medications would Dr. Rajan most likely prescribe to effectively treat both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cefixime + Azithromycin

 

  •  According to the syndromic approach for managing STIs/RTIs, the preferred treatment for both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis involves a combination of Azithromycin and Cefixime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young girl presented with a history of multiple episodes of loss of consciousness that lasted for 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur only in front of family members and only in the daytime. The patient can recall the conversation that happened around her during these episodes; there is no history of tongue bite and no incontinence. What is the preferred treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treat with behavioral therapy

  

The patient's symptoms—episodes of apparent loss of consciousness only occurring in front of family members, during the day, with the ability to recall surrounding conversations—suggest that these are not true seizures but pseudoseizures, which are commonly associated with conversion disorder.

 

Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms without a medical or neurological cause, often triggered by psychological factors.

 

Behavioral therapy is the preferred treatment for conversion disorder. This approach helps the patient address and modify the underlying psychological factors contributing to their symptoms through techniques such as cognitive restructuring, relaxation techniques, and coping strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treat with aversive therapy: Aversive therapy involves applying unpleasant stimuli to reduce the occurrence of undesirable behaviors. It is considered unethical, especially in treating psychological disorders like conversion disorder, because it can cause harm and does not address the underlying psychological issues.

 

Option C. Valproate: Valproate is an antiepileptic medication used to treat true seizures, but it is not appropriate for conversion disorder or pseudoseizures since the condition is psychological rather than neurological.

 

Option D.  Ketogenic diet: The ketogenic diet is sometimes used to manage epilepsy but is not suitable for conversion disorder. The diet has no role in addressing psychological origins of symptoms like pseudoseizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred treatment for conversion disorder, which manifests with pseudoseizures, is behavioral therapy, not antiepileptic drugs or other seizure management strategies.

questions.text: Which is the investigation of choice for Best disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Electrooculogram (EOG)

 

Explanation: 


Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease. EOG is the only condition where best disease has significant diagnostic value, and Best disease is the only condition where EOG is of primary diagnostic significance. In Best disease, the Arden ratio (peak to trough ratio) in EOG is abnormal (<1.5) while ERG remains normal in early stages. EOG measures the standing potential between the front and back of the eye and is particularly sensitive to RPE function, which is primarily affected in Best disease.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Electroretinogram (ERG):This is incorrect because ERG is typically normal in Best disease, especially in early stages. ERG measures the electrical response of the retina to light stimulation and primarily tests photoreceptor function.

 

Option C. Visual Evoked potential: This is incorrect because VEP tests the integrity of the entire visual pathway from retina to occipital cortex and is not specific for Best disease. It records the electrical activity in the visual cortex in response to visual stimuli.

 

Option D. Multifocal electro retinogram: This is incorrect because mfERG, while useful for evaluating macular function, is not the primary diagnostic test for Best disease. It provides topographic measurement of retinal electrophysiological activity in the central retina.

 

Educational Objective: 


Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease, with an abnormal Arden ratio (<1.5) being diagnostic while ERG remains normal in early stages.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).

 

Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4), which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.

 

Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1).

 

Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

 

Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia and left Horner's syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right-side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Lateral Medullary syndrome/Wallenburg syndrome which occurs due to PICA occlusion. His syndrome is characterized by a range of neurological deficits due to ischemia in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata, where PICA provides blood supply.

 

Clinical Features Associated with PICA Occlusion:

 

  • Vertigo and Diplopia: Caused by the involvement of the vestibular nuclei and adjacent structures.
  • Hoarseness and Dysphagia: Result from damage to the nucleus ambiguous, affecting the vagal and glossopharyngeal nerve functions.
  • Horner’s Syndrome: Occurs due to disruption of the sympathetic pathways.
  • Numbness of the Face and Contralateral Limbs: Caused by damage to the spinal trigeminal nucleus and the spinothalamic tract, respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA): Affects a similar region but typically presents with symptoms like hearing loss due to its supply to the inner ear structures, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option C. Superior Cerebellar Artery: Occlusion typically results in ataxia and coordination difficulties without the cross-sensory loss observed in Wallenberg's Syndrome.

 

Option D. Basilar Artery: A much broader array of symptoms would be expected, potentially affecting multiple cranial nerve and long tract functions simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Image: Arteries involved in brainstem syndromes lateral vs medial brainstem

 

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Chap 426, Neurology/stroke

choices.text: White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one does not indicate drowning prior to death:(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Washerwoman's hands and feet

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet just indicates that body was immersed in water. It does not specify whether the person died due to drowning or not. It occurs due to infiltration of water into the outer layers of the skin, which will occur irrespective whether the person died due to drowning or the body was thrown in water after death.

 

 

If a body is recovered from water, the there are two different kind of signs to look for:

 

  1. Signs of Antemortem Drowning: These will indicate that person died due to drowning.
  2. Signs of Immersion: These will only indicate that the body was in water.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning (in descending order of accuracy):

 

  • Grass or weeds tightly held in hands (cadaveric Spasm): Surest sign
  • Drowning Froth Over Mouth and Nose and in air passages: Second best sign
  • Emphysema Aquosum (overinflated lungs)
  • Presence of sand / mud etc. in respiratory passages especially in terminal part
  • Diatom test
  • Presence of water especially if mixed with mud / sand etc. in Stomach or intestines
  • Paltauff Haemorrhage (Subpleural Haemorrhage)
  • Gettler’s test

 

Signs of Immersion

 

  • Washerwoman’s hand / feet
  • Cutis anserina=goose skin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in stomach: This suggests that the person was alive when entering the water and swallowed water, indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils: This foam, often referred to as "drowning froth," is a strong indicator of antemortem drowning as it forms when water mixes with air and mucus in the airways.

 

Option D. Positive diatom test: The presence of diatoms in the organs indicates that the person inhaled water while still alive, allowing these microscopic algae to enter the bloodstream and be deposited in various tissues, thus confirming antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet indicate immersion in water but do not specify drowning as the cause of death, unlike other indicators such as water in the stomach, white leathery foam, and a positive diatom test, which strongly suggest antemortem drowning.

choices.text: This action can be reversed by phenylephrine.
﻿﻿﻿It cannot be reversed by levallorphan.
﻿﻿﻿It is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.
﻿﻿﻿Tolerance develops to this adverse effect on long-term use.

questions.text: A patient with a history of substance addiction is admitted to the hospital due to the overdose of the addictive substance. The patient has slow heart rate, respiratory depression, and low blood pressure. His ocular findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.
 

The pupil is constricted in the given image and as the history describes the patient to be an addict, who is brought to the hospital in an intoxicated state. The clinical features like pin-point pupils, bradycardia, hypotension, respiratory depression suggests that this is a case of opioid intoxication.


Opioid induced miosis:

 

  • The pupillary constriction caused by opioids result due to the activation of the Edinger Westphal Nucleus. Therefore, topical use of opioids in the eye does not induce miosis. It will be seen only on systemic administration of opioids.
  • The miosis induced by opioids cannot be reversed by mydriatic drugs like phenylephrine or anticholinergic drugs. Rather it can be reversed by opioid antagonists like naloxone and levallorphan.
  • Tolerance does not develop to opioid induced miosis even on long term use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This action can be reversed by phenylephrine: Phenylephrine is a mydriatic agent that causes dilation of the pupil by stimulating alpha-1 adrenergic receptors. It would not reverse opioid-induced miosis, which is due to central nervous system effects rather than direct effects on the iris muscles.

 

Option B. It cannot be reversed by levallorphan: Levallorphan is an opioid antagonist that can reverse the effects of opioid toxicity, including miosis. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option D. Tolerance develops to this adverse effect on long-term use: Tolerance to opioid-induced miosis does not typically develop, even with long-term use of opioids. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioid-induced miosis is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, and it is a characteristic sign of opioid intoxication. This effect cannot be reversed by phenylephrine, and tolerance does not develop to this effect with long-term opioid use. Opioid antagonists like naloxone and levallorphan can reverse the miosis caused by opioid overdose

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with complaint of sudden diminishing vision. On examination, relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the right eye and the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. MRI brain and orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • The presented clinical features suggest optic neuritis, which is characterized by sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss along with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • The recommended investigations for optic neuritis include MRI brain and orbit, screening for circulating MOG and NMO antibodies, and checking blood sugar levels.
  • Brain MRI is suggested in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis, as there is a high probability of developing multiple sclerosis.
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis that can occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. The presence of MOG and MO antibodies can diagnose the condition.
  • Reason for checking blood glucose level-
    • If it turns out to be optic neuritis, blood glucose levels should be measured as steroids are mainstay treatment modality
  • Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates RAPD, is a characteristic sign of optic neuritis. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test, where the eyes' response to light is observed by swinging the flashlight multiple times.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Thyroid profile: This is generally not directly relevant to acute visual changes associated with optic neuritis unless there is a suspicion of thyroid eye disease, which typically presents with other distinctive signs such as exophthalmos, eyelid retraction, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of sudden visual loss with RAPD, it is crucial to perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. MRI of the brain and orbits, along with specific antibody tests for MOG and NMO, provide critical information for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of optic neuritis and related conditions. Monitoring blood sugar levels is also essential, especially in the context of potential steroid therapy.

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition:(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Folate

 

  • Folate deficiency is the correct answer. Folate (also known as vitamin B9) plays a crucial role in DNA synthesis and repair. When there is a deficiency in folate, it can lead to the misincorporation of Uracil into DNA, causing DNA instability and other genetic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12: A deficiency in vitamin B12 is not directly associated with the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects red blood cell production and neurological functions.

 

Option B. B6: A deficiency in vitamin B6 is also not directly related to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms but does not cause Uracil incorporation into DNA.

 

Option D. Vit E: Vitamin E deficiency does not lead to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin E is primarily known for its antioxidant properties and its role in maintaining cell membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, who had visited multiple plastic surgeons requesting correction of "face deformity," was referred to a Psychiatrist. The patient insists that her face is deformed and needs surgery despite no evidence of deformity in the examination. The patient persists with her demand despite family members’ and doctors' reassurances. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SSRI

 

The patient described in the question is suffering from Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). BDD is a mental health condition characterized by an excessive preoccupation with an imagined defect in appearance, or if a minor physical anomaly is present, the person's concern is markedly excessive. Patients often have poor or absent insight, believing firmly in the existence of their perceived defects.

 

The standard treatment for BDD includes Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) (DOC) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Even when a patient's insight is at a delusional level, SSRIs remain the first-line pharmacological treatment, as they help reduce obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors associated with the disorder. In this case, SSRIs would be the best management option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behavioural therapy: While behavioral therapy might offer some benefits, the specific first-line treatment for BDD is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which targets the distorted beliefs about appearance directly. The term "Behavioral Therapy" is broad and less specific, making SSRIs a more targeted choice.

 

Option C. Atypical antipsychotics: These medications are not considered first-line treatment for BDD. They may be used as adjuncts in severe cases where delusional beliefs persist despite SSRIs, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Option D. Allow her for surgery: Surgery is not a recommended treatment for BDD as it does not address the underlying psychiatric condition and often worsens the patient's mental health state by reinforcing their preoccupation with appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), especially when insight is poor or absent, SSRIs are the drug of choice for management, often in combination with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Surgery is contraindicated as it does not address the core psychological issue.

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate termination

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described indicates fetal compromise, specifically with the findings of oligohydramnios (AFI = 5) and absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler. These are signs of severe placental insufficiency and fetal distress.

 

  • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound indicating severe fetal compromise. The absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery suggests that the fetus is not receiving adequate blood flow, leading to an increased risk of hypoxia and stillbirth.
  • Management:
    • Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks: This is not appropriate because the immediate risk to the fetus requires prompt delivery.

 

Option C. Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion: Continuous monitoring is insufficient in this scenario as the condition indicates severe fetal distress requiring urgent intervention.

 

Option D. Terminate after 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks is not appropriate due to the immediate risk of fetal compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe fetal compromise indicated by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler, especially beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate termination of the pregnancy is warranted to prevent fetal hypoxia and potential stillbirth.

 

Ref: Page no 2141, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enhancer deletion

 

Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene. On the contrary, deletion of an enhancer would likely reduce the expression of the gene, potentially reducing its oncogenic potential, rather than increasing it.

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promoter insertion: Can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene by increasing gene transcription.

 

Option C. Gene amplification: Leads to an increased number of gene copies, enhancing gene product levels, and contributing to oncogenesis.

 

Option D. Point mutation: A common mechanism for converting proto-oncogenes to oncogenes by altering the protein product to make it constitutively active.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transformation of proto-oncogene (i.e., normal cell proliferation gene) to oncogenes (i.e., cancer cell proliferation gene) may occur by three mechanisms:

 

  1. Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription. 
  2. Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls.  Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22.
  3. Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region,  ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 549-551

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 48 hours: Not the specified duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option B. 7 days: Not the maximum duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option D. 90 days: Far exceeds the duration mentioned in the act for voluntary self-admission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use has developed confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for this presentation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

 

The patient's presentation of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, along with a history of chronic alcohol use, is indicative of a deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine). This clinical picture is consistent with Wernicke's Encephalopathy, a serious neurological disorder most commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Alcohol use can lead to poor dietary intake and absorption, contributing to thiamine deficiency. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the triad of mental confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency in Vitamin B2 can lead to symptoms like skin disorders, anemia, and sore throat, but it is not typically associated with the neurological symptoms described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): While Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, they are typically peripheral neuropathies or seizures, not the classic triad seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and poor wound healing, which are not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic alcohol use presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, a Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency leading to Wernicke's Encephalopathy should be considered.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female underwent hip replacement. After 1 year, she developed fever and pain in the joint. Radiograph revealed loosening of prosthesis. The implant had to be removed. The histological image of the tissue adjoining the implant is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metallosis

 

  • The microscopic image shows multiple foci of extracellular metal deposits (seen as black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.

 

METALLOSIS

 

  • Metallosis is a rare, potentially fatal complication after arthroplasty characterized by the deposition and build-up of metal debris in the soft tissues of the body, associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices, but it has also been described in non-metallic prostheses.
  • It is defined as aseptic fibrosis, local necrosis, or loosening of a device secondary to metal corrosion and release of wear debris.
  • It occurs due to metallic erosion and release of metallic debris products, which induce massive local cytokines liberation from inflammatory cells.
  • It can present with local/systemic symptoms and signs due to a chronic inflammatory host response.
  • The local effects have been described as pseudotumours or osteolysis.
  • The systemic effects are caused by an immunological response to metal debris, including constitutional symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and malaise, cognitive impairment, haematological abnormalities and neuromuscular changes.
  • Risk factor for the development of metallosis include female gender, bilateral implants, high doses of corticosteroids, renal insufficiency and a suppressed immune system.
  • Its histology is characterized by widespread lymphoplasmacytic and histiocytic infiltration around metal debris, foreign body giant cells, metal particles, extracellular metal deposits and intracytoplasmic debris in giant cells.
  • Treatment consists of surgical revision with replacement of the prosthesis components, complete surgical debridement of osteolytic lesions and bone grafting with allograft chips.
  • Complete removal of all metal debris is difficult and may result in extensive tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma. Melanoma, also known as malignant melanoma, is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes. Melanomas typically occur in the skin. In women, they most commonly occur on the legs, while in men, they most commonly occur on the back. About 25% of melanomas develop from moles. Changes in a mole that can indicate melanoma include an increase in size, irregular edges, change in color, itchiness, or skin breakdown. The primary cause of melanoma is ultraviolet light (UV) exposure in those with low levels of the skin pigment melanin. Those with many moles, a history of affected family members, and poor immune function are at greater risk. Diagnosis is by biopsy. Using sunscreen and avoiding UV light may prevent melanoma. Treatment is typically removal of the melanoma and potentially affected tissue (border around the melanoma) by surgery. In those with slightly larger cancers, nearby lymph nodes may be tested for metastasis. For those in whom melanoma has spread, immunotherapy, biologic therapy, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy may improve survival. 

 

Option C. Ochronosis. Ochronosis is named for the reddish-brown hue of tissue termed "ochre-like". It is inborn error of metabolism. Ochronosis is due to deposition of a phenolic compound – "alkaptons" polymerizing into connective tissue, leading to black urine disease called alkaptonuria. Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, alkaptonuria is an inactive gene, mapped on chromosome 3q21-23 coding for the enzyme homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD). The result is systemic sequestration of homogentisate, that upon the decay to benzoquinone, can irreversibly bind with collagen. Polymerization of this molecule takes on an iridescent dark hue, tinting affected tissue and turning urine black. Aside from just discoloration, these processes can cause degradation, degeneration, and developmental problems in all types of collagen. The earliest sign is from parents who notice infants’ diapers are black in color. This disease can be insidious and manifest later in life. Patients may present with back pain or large joint arthralgias in their post-teenage years or early 30s. Pigmentation of the sclera and pinna of the ear is often seen later in life. Constant tendon ruptures especially with minimal trauma. On physical examination, thickened Achilles tendon and bursa effusions are common. For alkaptonuria, a chromatography assay in the urine for homogentisate can be diagnostic, especially, if the color change is noted after being exposed to the air. A genetic test can determine the existence of the autosomal recessive disease.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman syndrome. Rosai-Dorfman disease is a disease that occurs when the body produces too many histiocytes in the lymph nodes. These histiocytes accumulate in the cervical nodes most commonly. Histiocytes may also build up in the skin, upper respiratory tract, and sinuses. Rosai-Dorfman disease is seldom life-threatening. In many instances, the patient’s symptoms resolve on their own. The majority of patients experience enlarged lymph nodes on both sides of the neck. While often painless, these nodes can swell and grow rather larger. Swelling may also be reported in the lymph nodes of the groin, armpits, and in the central portion of the chest. This swelling may be accompanied by fever. The diagnosis is made following a tissue biopsy from the affected site. Though it is most commonly diagnosed in the first 10 years of life, it is also found in adults, affecting men and women equally. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows extracellular metal deposits (black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.
  • It is associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thomas test

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allis test. The Galeazzi test, also called Allis test, is used to assess hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) and can also be used to assess significant leg length inequality. The examination is performed with the child lying supine and their hips flexed to 45 degrees with knees flexed to 90 degrees, and feet on examining table. In this position, look for symmetry in the level of the knees. Galeazzi’s test is positive if the height of the knees is asymmetrical, and may be due to hip dislocation, DDH, congenital femoral shortening, fracture, other congenital conditions. It is also helpful in determining whether the leg length inequality is primarily from the femur or the tibia and can be used to assess leg length with knee or hip flexion contracture.

 

 

Option C. Ober test. The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB). The patient should be in side-lying with the affected side up. Bottom knee and hip should be flexed to flatten the lumbar curve. Stand behind the patient and firmly stabilize the pelvis/greater trochanter to prevent movement in any direction. Grasp the distal end of the patient’s affected leg with your other hand and flex the leg to a right angle at the knee. Extend and abduct the hip joint. Slowly lower the leg towards the table, adduct hip until motion is restricted. Ensure that the hip does not internally rotate and flex during the test and the pelvis must be stabilized. As allowing the thigh to drop in flexion and internal rotation would 'give in' to the tight TFL and not accurately test the length. If the ITB is normal, the leg will adduct with the thigh dropping down slightly below the horizontal, the test is called negative. If the ITB is tight, the leg would remain in the abducted position and the patient would experience lateral knee pain, the test is called positive.

 

 

Option D. Trendelenburg test. The aim of Trendelenburg’s test is to assess the strength of the hip abductors, specifically the gluteus medius and minimus. It is done when a patient complains of a limp, or hip pain or as part of a normal physical examination assessing gait. If the patient is comfortable to stand alone, stand behind the patient. Alternatively, stand in front of the patient, with their forearms positioned on yours to support them. Ask the patient to lift each foot in turn off the ground. When the patient lifts their right foot, the left hip abductors are being tested. When the patient lifts their left foot, the right hip abductors are being tested. Position your hands on the patient’s iliac crests. Observe carefully if the hip on the unsupported side lifts or droops. If the patient is using your arms for support, you will feel them pressing down on one of your arms if their hip abductors are unable to support their weight. A positive Trendelenburg’s sign (pathological) involves sagging of the pelvis on the unsupported side due to the abductor muscles failing to stabilise the hip towards the weight-bearing femur.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thomas test is used to assess the hip flexor contracture.

choices.text: 10% buffered formalin
95% ethyl alcohol
None of the above

questions.text: Fixative for PAP smear: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 95% ethyl alcohol

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. This fixative preserves the cellular detail necessary for accurate cytological evaluation by preventing cellular autolysis and degradation. The use of 95% ethyl alcohol ensures that the cells maintain their morphology, which is critical for detecting abnormalities such as dysplasia or carcinoma.

 

  • 95% Ethyl Alcohol: This is the standard fixative for Pap smears, ensuring optimal preservation of cellular details.
  • Ethanol Spray: In modern practice, an ethanol spray fixative is available, which can be conveniently used in an office setting to fix the smear immediately after it is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% buffered formalin: This fixative is typically used for histological specimens rather than cytological smears like the Pap test.

 

Option C. Air dried: Air drying is not recommended for Pap smears as it can cause cellular distortion and artifacts, which complicate the interpretation of the smear.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as 95% ethyl alcohol is the correct fixative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol, which preserves cellular morphology necessary for accurate cytological evaluation.

 

Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below used in laparoscopic surgeries? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The instrument in the image is Veress Needle.

 

The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. It consists of a long, slender needle with a sharp, pointed tip and a hollow center. The needle is attached to a handle and a valve that controls the flow of gas into the abdominal cavity.

 

The Veress needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity through a small incision, usually in the umbilicus (closed technique). The surgeon first lifts the abdominal wall away from the underlying organs and tissues, then inserts the Veress needle at a 45-degree angle to the skin and advances it until it reaches the abdominal cavity. The valve is then opened to allow gas (usually carbon dioxide) to flow into the abdominal cavity, creating a space for the laparoscope and other instruments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morris' needle: This is not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum or laparoscopic access.

 

Option C. Yankauer suction tip: This is a suction instrument used to clear surgical sites of blood and fluids, not for gas insufflation.

 

Option D. Von Graefe needle: Primarily used in ophthalmic procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of the Veress needle helps to minimize the risk of injury to surrounding organs and tissues during laparoscopic procedures. It is typically used at the beginning of the procedure, after which the laparoscope and other instruments are inserted through separate ports or trocars placed in the abdomen. The Veress needle is then removed and the incision closed.

questions.text: In the figure shown below, mechanism of action of valproate is best represented by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Mechanisms of Action of Sodium Valproate

 

  1. Enhancement of GABA Activity:
    • Valproate increases the levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. This is achieved primarily by stimulating the enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase that helps in formation of GABA from glutamic acid. Valproate also acts by inhibiting GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA breakdown, leading to increased GABA availability.
  2. Inhibition of Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels:
    • Valproate modulates voltage-gated sodium channels in the neurons. By prolonging the recovery of these channels from inactivation, valproate reduces the high-frequency repetitive firing of action potentials.
  3. Inhibition of T-Type Calcium Channels:
    • Valproate also affects T-type calcium channels, particularly in thalamic neurons. By inhibiting these channels, it reduces the rhythmic cortical discharges that are often seen in absence seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B represents the mechanism of action of drugs like gabapentin and pregabalin. These act by increasing the release of GABA.

 

Option C. C represents the mechanism of action of tiagabine. It acts by inhibiting the reuptake of GABA.

 

Option D. D is site of action of benzodiazepines like diazepam and lorazepam.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate increases GABA levels by stimulating the enzyme GAD (glutamic acid decarboxylase) to convert glutamate into GABA and by inhibiting GABA transaminase, preventing the breakdown of GABA.

questions.text:
For the detection of Diabetes Mellitus in a population over 40 but less than 60, two screening tests are performed simultaneously, without considering the result of one before conducting the other. This method leads to:


1. Decreased Specificity for detecting DM
2. Increased Sensitivity for detecting DM
3. Increased Negative Predictive Value
4. Increased Specificity for detecting DM
5. Reduced sensitivity for detecting diabetes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

When two screening tests are used in parallel, both tests are performed independently, and the results of one test do not influence whether the second test is done. The primary purpose of using tests in parallel is to increase the likelihood of detecting a condition if it is present, which affects sensitivity and predictive values as follows:

 

1. Increased Sensitivity for detecting DM (B): Performing tests in parallel increases the overall sensitivity, meaning that more cases of diabetes mellitus are likely to be detected. This is because if either test returns positive, the condition is considered present, reducing the chance of a false negative.

 

2. Decreased Specificity for detecting DM (A): While sensitivity increases, specificity decreases. This occurs because a higher likelihood of obtaining a positive result also means there is an increased chance of false positives, thereby reducing specificity.

 

3. Increased Negative Predictive Value (C): Negative Predictive Value (NPV) improves because if both tests come back negative, there is a very high probability that the person does not have diabetes mellitus. Thus, the reliability of a negative result is strengthened.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Increased Specificity for detecting DM: Incorrect, Using tests in parallel reduces specificity because the probability of a false positive increases when either test is sufficient for a positive result.

 

5. Decreased Sensitivity for detecting DM: Incorrect, The sensitivity actually increases when tests are used in parallel, as the likelihood of detecting true positive cases is higher.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Performing two screening tests in parallel increases sensitivity and negative predictive value while decreasing specificity.

questions.text: A patient with heart disease has breathlessness on going to the bathroom. What grade does he belong to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NYHA 3

 

This patient with heart disease experiences dyspnea while performing an activity of daily living (going to the bathroom), which classifies him as NYHA Class 3.

 

The New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification system is used to classify patients with heart disease based on their functional disability:

 

  • NYHA Class I: No limitation of physical activity; ordinary activity does not cause symptoms.
  • NYHA Class II: Slight limitation of physical activity; comfortable at rest, but ordinary activity causes symptoms.
  • NYHA Class III: Marked limitation of physical activity; comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary activity (e.g., walking to the bathroom) causes symptoms.
  • NYHA Class IV: Unable to carry out any physical activity without symptoms, or symptoms at rest.

 

In this case, the patient's breathlessness when going to the bathroom indicates a significant limitation, making him fall under Class III.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NYHA 4: Class 4 indicates severe limitations, where the patient is unable to perform any activity without symptoms or experiences symptoms even at rest, which is more severe than this patient’s current condition.

 

Option C. MMRC 4 and D. MMRC 5: The Modified Medical Research Council (MMRC) Dyspnea Scale is used to assess dyspnea in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). This classification scale does not apply to patients with heart disease. The MMRC scale is used to assess the degree of breathlessness in COPD, ranging from 0 to 4, where higher numbers indicate more severe breathlessness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The NYHA classification is commonly used to evaluate patients with heart failure based on their level of physical activity and symptom severity. Class III patients experience significant limitations in activity, where even mild exertion (such as going to the bathroom) causes symptoms like breathlessness.

choices.text: Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount

questions.text: The maximum thermic effect is seen with a meal which has? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Protein

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food.

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat: Fats have a moderate thermic effect, lower than proteins.

 

Option C. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have the lowest thermic effect.

 

Option D. Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount: A mixed meal would have a combined thermic effect that is a weighted average of the individual macronutrient effects, which would be lower than that of a protein-only meal.

 

Real-world Observation: It is commonly observed that after consuming a protein-rich meal, especially during hot weather, individuals may feel hot and humid due to the increased heat production. Conversely, in cold weather, the same meal can provide a warming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum thermic effect is seen with protein-rich meals, as proteins require more energy for digestion, absorption, and metabolism compared to fats and carbohydrates.

questions.text:
In the given section of the heart, match the marked (4, 9, 12, 1) structures:

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)
  2. Mitral valve
  3. Tricuspid valve
  4. Papillary muscles
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a-1, b-4, c-9, D-12

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cut and reflected section of the heart.

 

The ventricles can be identified based upon the wall thickness - Left ventricle has thicker walls.

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (marked as 1): This structure represents the exit point for blood traveling to the lungs for oxygenation.
  2. Mitral valve (marked as 4): Located between the left atrium and the left ventricle, the mitral valve regulates blood flow within the heart.
  3. Tricuspid valve (marked as 9): This valve, situated between the right atrium and right ventricle, prevents backflow of blood from the ventricles to the atria.
  4. Papillary muscles (marked as 12): These muscles are attached to the ventricular walls and play a critical role in the function of the mitral and tricuspid valves via tendon-like chords.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match is:

 

1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)

2. Left atrium

3. Pulmonary veins (light red)

4. Mitral valve

5. Aorta (red).

6. Superior vena cava (blue)

7. Aortic semi lunar valve

8. Right atrium

9. Tricuspid valve

10. Right ventricle

11. Inferior vena cave (blue)

12. Papillary muscles

13. Left ventricle

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the following EEG finding? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM sleep

 

EEG recording is showing "Sawtooth waves" which are characteristic of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is also associated with rapid eye movements, muscle atonia (paralysis), and dreaming.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Transition between wakefulness and sleep, contains theta waves.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, characterized by delta waves.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep follows NREM sleep. EEG in REM sleep shows sawtooth waves and increased activity similar to awake state (beta activity) along with return of alpha activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 534.

choices.text: More common after life threatening trauma
Seen in seizure and migraine patients
Mean age at onset is 25 years

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding depersonalization disorder? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seen in seizure and migraine patients

 

This is a controversial question as the interpretation of question can be different but based on the given options, the most appropriate answer will be option B. 


As per CTP 11th Edition – Depersonalization is seen in a variety of neurologic and psychiatric disorders and is common in complex partial seizures

 

Depersonalization disorder (DPD) is characterized by persistent or recurrent feelings of detachment or estrangement from one's own thoughts, emotions, body, or surroundings.

 

DPD can be associated with other medical conditions, including seizure disorders and migraines, as stated in option B.
 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. While it can occur as a reaction to life-threatening trauma, it is not specifically more common after such events. 


As per CTP 11th Edition – Many individuals with depersonalization/derealization disorder do not identify an immediate traumatic antecedent and do not report a clear precipitant to disorder onset. On the other hand, nontraumatic stressors—such as severe interpersonal, financial, or occupational losses—have been associated with the onset or exacerbation of the disorder.
 

Option C. The disorder has a slight male predominance.

 

Option D. The mean age of onset for depersonalization disorder is typically in the mid to late teens, not 25 years.
 

Educational Objective: 

 

Depersonalisation disorder is characterized by feelings of unreality or detachment from oneself or one’s body. The patients feel ‘as if’ they have changed. They can be associated with medical conditions such as migraine, seizure disorder, cerebral tumors and encephalitis.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 110

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with a history of loss of interest in day-to-day activities, weight loss, insomnia, and sadness for six months. She also recalls hearing a voice once that ordered her to kill herself. What is the DSM-V diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

 

The patient's symptoms of loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness align with major depressive disorder. The presence of auditory hallucination (voice ordering her to commit suicide) indicates an additional psychotic feature. Hence, the diagnosis would be Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: It is a chronic disorder typically lasting more than 6 months, with symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc. without a predominant mood episode.

 

Option C. Schizoaffective disorder: It has features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders concurrently.

 

Option D. Delusional disorder: The primary feature is a persistent delusion without other symptoms of psychosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder. Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

 

For the management of premature ejaculation, the Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method that is often recommended. This technique involves sexual stimulation until the individual is close to ejaculation. At that point, the partner squeezes the shaft of the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for several seconds, which can delay ejaculation. This process is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed to occur. The Squeeze Technique helps in increasing the time before ejaculation and is directly targeted at managing premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensate Focus Technique: While this technique, which involves non-genital pleasuring, can be helpful in reducing performance anxiety and improving sexual communication, it is not specifically designed for the treatment of premature ejaculation. It is useful for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not typically employed for premature ejaculation.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT can be useful for addressing underlying psychological issues contributing to sexual dysfunction, but it is a more general approach and not as specifically targeted for premature ejaculation as the Squeeze Technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.
